anchor.surface_text: ese two appeals arise out of two writ petitions filed by the appellant Kashiram Agarwala in the Punjab High Court, Circuit Bench, at Delhi challenging the validity of two orders passed by the Central Board of Revenue  hereinafter called the Board under s. 127 1  of the Income-Tax Act, 1961  No. 43 of 1961   hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: In Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India, validity of s.5(7A) of 1922 Act was challenged.

anchor.surface_text: In Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India 1  the validity of s. 5 7A  of the earlier Act of 1922 was challenged before this Court. The said section had provided that the Commissioner of Income-tax may transfer any case from one Income-tax Officer subordinate to him to another,

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the transfer authorised by s. 5 7A  would take the case from the jurisdiction of an officer entitled to try it under s. 64 1   2  to another officer who may number have jurisdiction to try the case under the said provision. concepts.interpretation: Dispenses with requirement of giving opportunity for transfers within same city/locality; court interprets it also dispenses with recording reasons as corollary.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  2  lays down that the transfer which is authorised to be made by sub-section  1 , can be made at any stage of the proceedings, and shall number render necessary the reissue of any numberice already issued by the Income-tax Officer from whom the case is transferred.

concepts.unlisted_description: Transfer at any stage, no reissue of notice

anchor.surface_text: Section 124 of the Act deals with the jurisdiction of Income-tax Officers. S. 124 3  provides that within the limits of the area assigned to him, the Income-tax Officer shall have jurisdiction-  a  in respect of any person carrying on a business or profession, if the place at which he carries on his business of profession is situate within the area, or where his business or profession is carried on in more places than one, if the principal place of his business or profession is situate within the area, and  b  in respect of any other person residing within -the area.

concepts.interpretation: Fixes jurisdiction of ITOs; intra-locality transfer is administrative, no prejudice.

issues.text: Whether the impugned transfer orders under s.127(1) of the Income-Tax Act, 1961 are invalid because the Board failed to record reasons for the transfer

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner alleged that these two orders were invalid, because before exercising its power under s. 127 1 , the Board had failed to comply with a mandatory requirement prescribed by the said provision.

issues.text: What is the effect of the proviso to s.127(1) of the Income-Tax Act, 1961, particularly whether it dispenses with the requirement of recording reasons for transfers within the same city, locality or place

anchor.surface_text: The question which calls for our decision in the present appeals is what is the effect of the proviso to s. 127  1  ? The proviso lays down that nothing in sub-section  1  shall be deemed to require any such opportunity to be given in a case like the present.

issues.text: Whether the proviso to s.127(1) dispenses only with the requirement of giving opportunity or also with recording reasons

anchor.surface_text: It is urged by Mr. Jain that the effect of the. proviso is that the requirement as to the giving of a reasonable ,opportunity alone is dispensed with in respect of cases falling under the proviso, but not the requirement as to the recording of reasons.

arguments.claim: The transfer orders passed by the Board under s.127(1) are invalid because the Board failed to comply with the mandatory requirement to record reasons.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner alleged that these two orders were invalid, because before exercising its power under s. 127 1 , the Board had failed to comply with a mandatory requirement prescribed by the said provision.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: its power under s. 127 1 , the Board had failed to companyply with a mandatory requirement prescribed by the said provision. These petitions were dism

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso to s.127(1) dispenses with recording reasons for intra-locality transfers as they are administrative with no prejudice.

arguments.claim: s.127(1) imposes an obligation on the authority to record reasons for directing transfer of a case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: companying to the companyclusion that it is number possible to give the required opportunity to the assessee, the authority must act reasonably and b

arguments.court_reasoning: Reasons requirement is corollary to opportunity, both dispensed by proviso for same locality transfers.

arguments.claim: The proviso to s.127(1) dispenses only with the requirement of giving reasonable opportunity, but not with recording reasons.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged by Mr. Jain that the effect of the. proviso is that the requirement as to the giving of a reasonable ,opportunity alone is dispensed with in respect of cases falling under the proviso, but not the requirement as to the recording of reasons.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: panysidering the effect of the proviso. Besides, it would number be unreasonable to assume that the recording of reasons prescribed by S. 127 1  would

arguments.court_reasoning: Literal supports but purposive reading, considering corollary nature and administrative context, rejects it.

arguments.claim: Under s.127(1), opportunity to be heard is discretionary (wherever possible) but recording reasons is mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: It will be noticed that s. 127 1 requires that where the power conferred by it is intended to be exercised, an opportunity should be given to the assessee wherever it is possible to do so, and reasons have to be recorded for making the order of transfer.

arguments.claim: Requirement to record reasons is a natural corollary of giving opportunity; proviso dispensing opportunity also dispenses reasons.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, it would not be unreasonable to assume that the recording of reasons prescribed by S. 127 1 would be appropriate where a transfer is being made otherwise than in the manner prescribed by the proviso. In such a case, normally, the assessee has to be given a reasonable opportunity

arguments.claim: Intra-locality transfers under proviso are purely administrative for departmental convenience, causing no prejudice, hence no need for opportunity or reasons.

anchor.surface_text: Section 124 of the Act deals with the jurisdiction of Income-tax Officers. ... Such an order is purely in the nature of an administrative order passed for considerations of convenience of the department and no possible prejudice can be involved in such a transfer.

arguments.claim: Legislative history and Pannalal Binjraj show opportunity/reasons requirements apply to inter-place transfers, not intra-locality ones.

anchor.surface_text: In Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India 1 the validity of s. 5 7A of the earlier Act of 1922 was challenged before this Court. ... the propriety of giving an opportunity to an assessee and the desirability of recording reasons which this Court emphasised, had reference to cases where transfers were intended to be made from an Income-tax Officer in one place to the Income-tax Officer in another place

arguments.claim: Impugned orders valid; cannot be challenged for not recording reasons as proviso applies to same locality transfer.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold the impugned orders cannot be challenged on the ground that Board has not recorded reasons in directing the transfer of the pending against the assessee from one Income-tax Officer other in the same locality. The result is, the appeals fail and are dismissed.

holdings.text: Under s.127(1) of the Income-Tax Act, 1961, recording reasons for transfer is mandatory where opportunity is required.

anchor.surface_text: That, however, is number so with regard to the requirement that reasons must be recorded for making the transfer. So far as s. 127 1  is companycerned, there is numberdispute about this position. The question which calls for our decision in the present appeals is what is the effect of the proviso to s. 127  1  ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed position that reasons must be recorded generally, unlike discretionary opportunity.

holdings.text: The proviso to s.127(1) dispenses with both the requirement of giving opportunity and recording reasons for transfers from one Income-tax Officer to another in the same city, locality or place.

anchor.surface_text: The proviso lays down that numberhing in sub-section  1  shall be deemed to require any such opportunity to be given in a case like the present. It is plain that the transfer in the present case is from one Income-tax Officer to another whose offices are situated in the same locality and so, the point to companysider is, what is the effect of this proviso?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction: reasons are corollary to opportunity; intra-locality transfers administrative with no prejudice; legislative history from Pannalal Binjraj supports.

holdings.text: The effect of the proviso is not limited to dispensing with opportunity alone but also the recording of reasons.

anchor.surface_text: If the words used in the proviso are literally companystrued, it may have to be companyceded that there is some force in this companytention. But, on the other hand, the provision that numberhing in sub- section  1  shall be deemed to require any opportunity to be given, is worded in an emphatic form and that fact has to be home in mind in companysidering the effect of the proviso.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal supports narrow view but purposive rejects it as reasons flow from opportunity requirement.

holdings.text: Intra-locality transfers under proviso to s.127(1) are administrative orders for departmental convenience involving no prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: Section 124 of the Act deals with the jurisdiction of Income-tax Officers. S. 124 3  provides that within the limits of the area assigned to him, the Income-tax Officer shall have jurisdiction-  a  in respect of any person carrying on a business or profession, if the place at which he carries on his business of profession is situate within the area,... Such an order is purely in the nature of an administrative order passed for companysiderations of companyvenience of the department and numberpossible prejudice can be involved in such a transfer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction under s.124 allows competent officers interchangeably within area; no jurisdictional shift.

holdings.text: The impugned orders cannot be challenged for failure to record reasons as they involve transfer within the same locality.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold the impugned orders cannot be challenged on the ground that Board has number recorded reasons in directing the transfer of the pending against the assessee from one Income-tax Officer other in the same locality. The result is, the appeals fail and are dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of proviso interpretation to facts: same locality transfer.
